website_summaries.verdict: The best book on CSS programming written in a way to address everyday issues professionals are likely to encounter.
pros: The book is structured with a focus on troubleshooting common problems experienced in CSS development on the internet
Offers more situation-specific advice and solutions compared to most basic CSS books
cons: The content of the book does not have as much of the basic coverage on the CSS language as other books

customer_reviews.title: My new desk reference
customer_reviews.text: One of the five books I keep within arm's reach at all times while I'm working. This is an excellent book. It's very well written, has great examples, and is easy to read. Lea does a very good job communicating how to use some of the newfangled "CSS Tricks" in very real and practical ways. I've used much of what she's written in here in real projects for real clients. This isn't just some, "look at what CSS can do" kind of book. It offers good advice for how to use the latest features of CSS in a good way.
customer_reviews.author: Frank M. Taylor

customer_reviews.title: Love it!
customer_reviews.text: Lea Verou not only guides you step by step in better ways to do things you already know, but also guides you in a very straightforward way to learn some very tricky stuff. This book has become a consult headbook, and I'm a declared Lea fan.
customer_reviews.author: Jesus Lugo

customer_reviews.title: I did not see single useful line of CSS.
customer_reviews.text: I am a front end dev, I am not a new bee. I was looking to skill-up my CSS and this book showed up in Amazon search. I have read the book, nothing useful nothing that I didn't know.
customer_reviews.author: david

customer_reviews.title: Really helped me out.
customer_reviews.text: This helped me immensely in my early coding days. The tutorials are easy to follow and the book is very user-friendly. If you're just starting out with css, this book is sure to give you an edge, teach you some nifty tricks, and instill in you a love for the lesser known parts of the language.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Awesome book! Great addition to any designer or front end dev's shelf!
customer_reviews.text: So glad I ordered it to add to my library! Great book even for someone who is fluent in CSS... or at least thinks they are/were (like me) I thought I knew a lot but this book has clarified some things and taught me things I never even knew! Sure, a lot of this stuff can probably be found somewhere online but I would have never of even thought to search for it... Worth every penny!
customer_reviews.author: James Gilmore

customer_reviews.title: Lea Verou has dug deep into the inner workings of ...
customer_reviews.text: Lea Verou has dug deep into the inner workings of the latest CSS recommendations. If you know what is commonly referred to as CSS 2.1, CSS Secrets will take your skills well beyond.
customer_reviews.author: Kindle Customer

customer_reviews.title: Anyone who touches CSS code should own this book
customer_reviews.text: This is not a guide to every feature in the CSS spec, but it will teach you tons of tricks and round out your understanding of CSS. I read it cover to cover in two days and now recommend it to every developer I come across.
customer_reviews.author: dbbldz

customer_reviews.title: Advanced CSS Solutions
customer_reviews.text: These are some very specific solutions to a bunch of advanced CSS problems. Very pragmatic. Very useful. But, if you haven't learned CSS yet, this is not the book for you. For those looking to understand how some of those common problems are solved, this is VERY useful!
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: An incredible read for both highly specialized front-end developers, and generalists out there
customer_reviews.text: CSS Secrets was most definitely one of the greatest technical books about CSS I've ever read. The book breaks free from the format most academic books have, and this makes it incredibly easy to read. Throughout the reading process, the reader is able to see Lea Verou's dedication; illustrations, footnotes, and a more personal/informal approach to the writing, everything makes the reader feel comfortable and cared. As a plus, the fact that CSS Secrets is based on an intersection between front-end development and graphic design is going to be a delight for generalists out there seeking for a sympathetic mind.
customer_reviews.author: Nicolás J. Engler

customer_reviews.title: Best book for people who are familiar with CSS already
customer_reviews.text: Great book, very well explained. It has excellent examples and goes very into depth on all subjects. Highly recommended.

customer_reviews.title: Must have for frontend
customer_reviews.text: Is exactly what I was looking for, it help you go deep in CSS and solves several and common issues that every one need need to solve. This book is highlight recomended for frontend developers and every one who want build awesome sites.
customer_reviews.author: Luis M. Salido

customer_reviews.title: Cool Book!
customer_reviews.text: I like her writing style, I like the way the book was designed: it was really easy to see the problem and solution. Lea gives an introduction that was very informative. I didn't realize who comprised the W3C. Now I know. Get the book and you can know too.
customer_reviews.author: Sean

customer_reviews.title: Useful, applicable wisdom from a real CSS expert.
customer_reviews.text: A great collection of tips for getting more out of CSS than you ever expected was possible - Lea Verou is a CSS wizard. Many of the solutions she comes up with for common styling problems are like good riddles: ingenious and unexpected, yet they feel obvious once you know the answer. The tips she provides are pretty specific to particular use cases of CSS. This is great for web designers/developers running into the specific problems the tips address, but not as useful for a reader looking for more of a general understanding of CSS thinking (which it clearly states is not the aim of this book).
customer_reviews.author: Peter Valeo

customer_reviews.title: If you think you know CSS, better think again.

customer_reviews.title: An incredible insight into some of the most powerful new ...

Solutions for designs that are sought out for and an introduction into some upcoming browser implementations current and new. Any CSS monster should have this book as ammunition to take into solution based designs in whatever complications arise in designing for the web. Layout mastery should be a pre-cursor before reading but every page is a mind-exploding adventure into CSS.

customer_reviews.title: WOW!! Lea Verou knocks it out of the PARK!!
customer_reviews.text: Such an AMAZING BOOK by one of the "World's Best CSS Authors" in the Web Design modern era, Lea Verou. She has me thinking of things that I never thought were possible with CSS. From some very simple CSS tasks to advanced CSS that not your ordinary designer/dev would even think of doing or trying. The book is filled with great scenarios, fully thought out examples, mind blowing pointers that will leave you asking yourself, "Why didn't I think of this sooner?" This book is not for someone just starting out learning CSS, you should have a solid understanding of the Box model and CSS Layouts. This book has a permanent spot on my desk at work.
customer_reviews.author: Jason Hess

customer_reviews.title: I love this book
customer_reviews.text: Lea Verou is a genius, and I love this book. The book is well written and very easy to understand. I wouldn't say that all of the information in this book are things that you will be using every day but it's definitely there when you need it. Definitely not for beginners. If you are writing CSS for a living then you should get it. Some very nice things to learn and keep in back of your mind.

customer_reviews.title: awesome, but he talks a lot about css 2

customer_reviews.title: Not quite the CSS book I was looking for.
customer_reviews.text: I was looking for a book for an intermediate CSS software engineer looking to be a little more advanced, efficient, and disciplined about my layouts and how I create my css. This was small tricks for the most part, to get really cool gradients and backgrounds. There were lots of things I learned, and good things imparted... but I was looking for deep musical theory, and I got Tom Morrello. I would recommend Tiffany Brown 'CSS Master' if that is what you're looking for.
